docs.lead_paragraph: Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Missouri, the state's largest health insurer, is taking the state to court over its bid to collect hundreds of millions of dollars from the company. In a suit filed this week in Cole County, the company charges misconduct by the state's Insurance Department and asks a circuit judge to order regulators to relent.

headline.main: Blue Cross Lawsuit Filed Against Missouri

docs.lead_paragraph: It was two days before the White House was to convene its long-awaited conference this week on corporate responsibility, and Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich was warming to the theme. Increased political and media pressure recently placed on corporate executives over layoffs, he argued, had forced managers to think twice about downsizing their work forces. "Up until five months ago, it was common for C.E.O.'s to proudly proclaim to Wall Street their intentions to ax thousands if not tens of thousands of workers," Mr. Reich said in an interview. "In the last month, the announcements have been markedly different. C.E.O.'s have been reassuring Main Street that there will be few if any job losses."

headline.main: Bobbing and Weaving on Issue of Layoffs

docs.snippet: It was two days before the White House was to convene its long-awaited conference this week on corporate responsibility, and Labor Secretary Robert B.  Reich was warming to the theme. Increased political and media pressure recently  placed on...

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton deserves credit for what he did not say during this week's White House seminar on corporate responsibility. With polls registering high levels of anxiety over job security and stagnant wages, politicians are drawn to blaming managers. Some criticism is surely deserved, but corporation-bashing is no answer for everything that ails the economy. Mr. Clinton resisted the temptation to pick on easy targets or embrace reckless policy prescriptions. Instead, the daylong gathering of about 100 C.E.O.'s spotlighted companies that have treated their employees generously and also found ways to earn handsome profits. The White House's purpose was to praise "family-friendly" practices in the hope that other companies would emulate them. Starbucks, a chain of retail coffee outlets, provides health insurance even to its part-time employees. Fel-Pro, a maker of auto parts, provides employees flexible work schedules, day care and profit sharing. Other companies were applauded for providing on-site training and education benefits.

docs.lead_paragraph: Seeking to encourage American companies to take more responsibility for the well-being of their employees, President Clinton presided today over meetings and seminars with business executives that he said offered proof "you can do the right thing and make money." The summons of business leaders to a White House-sponsored Corporate Citizenship Conference was Mr. Clinton's latest attempt to use the President's bully pulpit to highlight an issue and challenge the private sector to meet social problems, without actually legislating change.

headline.main: Clinton Prods Executives to 'Do the Right Thing'

docs.lead_paragraph: For the first time since January, New Jersey will be sending out reimbursement checks to the 84 hospitals that provide free medical treatment to the uninsured, now that the state has finally agreed on a financing plan. Ending a five-month debate over how to pay for hospital care for the uninsured, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman signed the bill into law about an hour after it was approved 32 to 7 by the State Senate. The two-year plan continues to rely on payroll taxes designated for the state's unemployment fund and seeks to move the uninsured into a managed-care network that has yet to be created.

headline.main: Battle Ends On Free Care For Uninsured

docs.lead_paragraph: Pounded by budget cuts and intense competition from managed care, New York City's Health and Hospitals Corporation announced yesterday that it would lay off 1,600 unionized employees next month, many of them nurses and doctors involved in direct patient care. The job cuts mark the first time in well over a decade that the public hospitals have systematically laid off professional patient-care staff members. They also represent the first time that unionized public workers have lost their jobs since Rudolph W. Giuliani became Mayor.

headline.main: Hospitals Agency to Drop 1,600 Unionized Workers

docs.lead_paragraph: Two days of talks ended yesterday without agreement on ways to open up Japan's insurance industry to United States competition. No date has been set for the next meeting, but Japan is "willing to meet anytime, anywhere," an official of the Ministry of Finance said. The major disagreement remains over the so-called third-sector insurance, a niche that accounts for about 5 percent of Japan's overall market. In Japan, American companies now concentrate on third-sector coverage -- specialized insurance that Japanese companies do not offer, like supplemental health coverage for catastrophic illness, nursing care and personal accident insurance. (AP)

headline.main: Japan and U.S. Fail To Agree on Insurance

docs.lead_paragraph: After six weeks of trying to run for President from the well of the Senate, Bob Dole finally conceded today that his strategy was not working. But while he can take himself out of Congress and get a new backdrop for his speeches, this Congress will inevitably remain a big part of the Dole candidacy. He cannot escape being judged to some degree on the record it compiles and by its personality even after he goes.

docs.lead_paragraph: By this fall, most people receiving public assistance will be required to enroll in a health maintenance organization, state officials said yesterday. Last June, the state began shifting welfare recipients in four counties from traditional and more expensive health insurance plans to H.M.O. systems, and yesterday, the Federal Government authorized adding nine counties, said Laurie Facciarossa, a spokeswoman for the Department of Human Services.

docs.lead_paragraph: Some of the students at Jonathan Dayton High cried today for their school and their friends. Both are anchors of their adolescence. And both were left with murky futures on Tuesday night by a vote here and in five neighboring towns of Union County to dismantle New Jersey's oldest and, some argue, one of its premier regional high school districts.

headline.main: Schools Weigh Impact Of District Breakup
